   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is more stable from respiratory
   standpoint but active issues are now low grade fevers, leukocytosis of
   unclear origin, and delirium.
   .
   #)  Fevers/leukocytosis: Patient is intermittently febrile and now has
   a rising leukocytosis.  Cultures have not grown anything to date, but
   he has persistently been on antibiotics.  This could be from gout.  C
   diff NTD and pending from this morning.  CXR appears unchanged.  LFTs
   normal.  Has completed a course of Azithro, and have changed to Zosyn
   (empiric coverage of Pseudomonas), and continuing Vanco (for MRSA
   coverage).
   - Continuing Vanc/Zosyn for a [**7-3**] day course
   - F/u cultures, continue to re-culture if spikes (all are NTD, sputum
   culture is contaminated)
   - Needs new sputum Cx as the last one was inadequate
   - Rheum recommends  Colchicine for gout treatment; no steroids at this
   time- need to touch base with them about stopping prednisone.
   - Stopped tylenol and was afebrile; continue Tylenol for pain
   .
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - Have started Lasix 40 IV bid
   - metoprolol 37.5 mg QID
   - I/O goal
euvolemia to negative
   .
   #) AFib with RVR: dig loaded, level was 1.8 yesterday pm, only getting
   dosed every day. Will discuss on rounds starting on qday dosing.  Now
   in sinus rhythm
   - need EKG to confirm in sinus rhythm
   - Dose with digoxin today; was held yesterday d/t 1.8 Dig level.  Need
   to talk to pharm about recs
   - Metoprolol as above
   - INR very high yesterday, will convert and stop coumadin.
   - F/u coags this am
   .
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Has not had episodes of
   desaturation for several days but continues to require frequent
   suctioning.
   - Vanc/Zosyn as above.
   - diuresis
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - Continue as is, try to wean O2 as tolerated
   .
   #) Delerium: more interactive the last couple of days but continues to
   wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to communicate with his sons and
   they think he has improved.  Almost definitely has hospital/ICU
   delirium.
   - Should continue working with PT.
   - Standing Tylenol for pain control
 will give a trial off Tylenol to
   assess fevers
   - no benzos or other altering medications
   .
   #) Gout: Rheum consulted and tapped knee, fluid is consistent with
   gout. Could explain low grade fevers, increased WBC count.
   - Continues on Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday and we are hesitant to increase
   this further, pt already with delirium and possible infection
   - Started Colchicine yesterday
   - Has been on prednisone despite rheum recs not to be on it, will
   discuss with rheum today
   .
   #) Hypotension: resolved.  Will need close monitoring while being
   diuresed.
   .
   #) Left and right wrist fractures: Left side reduced and casted.  Right
   side splinted.  No plans for operative intervention.
   - will recontact ortho to take a look at the L cast which appears to be

   .

   - trend creatinine

    #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.3.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   .

   but has been prescribed them in the past.  We are giving albuterol and
   ipratropium nebulizers standing
   .

    .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 89-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and was transferred to the hospital with odontoid and right wrist fractures. The patient is currently experiencing low-grade fevers, leukocytosis of unclear origin, and delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Infection: The patient's persistent leukocytosis and low-grade fevers may indicate an underlying infection, which could be due to gout, C. difficile, or another bacterial or viral pathogen.
2. Gout: The patient's WBC count and low-grade fevers may be related to gout, which was diagnosed by rheumatology. The patient is currently on prednisone and colchicine, but the dose may need to be adjusted to manage the condition.
3. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's history of end-stage diastolic heart failure, severe aortic regurgitation, and moderate mitral regurgitation increases his risk of exacerbation. The patient is currently receiving IV diuretics and metoprolol to manage his condition.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's history of COPD and recent hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure increases his risk of respiratory complications, including pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium may be related to his underlying medical conditions, medication use, or infection. It is essential to continue working with the patient's family and caregivers to manage his delirium and prevent further complications.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to his chronic kidney disease, recent large bleed from the femoral line site, or other underlying medical conditions. It is essential to trend his hematocrit levels and consider transfusions as necessary.
7. Fractures: The patient's odontoid and right wrist fractures may require further management, including re-casting and physical therapy to prevent complications such as non-union or malunion.

Based on the patient's current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, lab results, and medical conditions closely to prevent further complications. The patient's family and caregivers should be educated on his condition and treatment plan to ensure optimal care.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with altered mental status following a fall. The patient has been experiencing rising leukocytosis, and cultures have been recultured. They are currently receiving Vanc/Zosyn antibiotics and colchicine. The patient's INR has increased significantly from 2.0 to 12.3, and Coumadin and subQ heparin have been discontinued.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 137/36 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and have a SpO2 of 91%. The patient's neurological status is unclear due to the altered mental status.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. The creatinine level is elevated, and the INR is significantly increased.

Potential medical complications:

1. Septic shock: The patient's rising leukocytosis and recultured cultures may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to septic shock.
2. Bleeding: The patient's increased INR and discontinuation of Coumadin and subQ heparin may increase the risk of bleeding.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's SpO2 of 91% may indicate respiratory failure, which can be exacerbated by the patient's altered mental status and decreased mobility.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level may indicate kidney injury, which can be exacerbated by the patient's underlying medical conditions and medications.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's increased risk of bleeding and altered mental status may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's recultured cultures and elevated white blood cell count may indicate the presence of an infection, which can lead to sepsis and septic shock.
7. Neurological decline: The patient's altered mental status may decline further, which can lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and altered mental status may increase the risk of pressure ulcers.
9. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's immobility and altered mental status may increase the risk of venous thromboembolism.
10. Medication errors: The patient's altered mental status and multiple medications may increase the risk of medication errors.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is more stable from respiratory
   standpoint but active issues are now low grade fevers, leukocytosis of
   unclear origin, and delirium.
   .
   #)  Fevers/leukocytosis: Patient is intermittently febrile and now has
   a rising leukocytosis.  Cultures have not grown anything to date, but
   he has persistently been on antibiotics.  This could be from gout.  C
   diff NTD and pending from this morning.  CXR appears unchanged.  LFTs
   normal.  Has completed a course of Azithro, and have changed to Zosyn
   (empiric coverage of Pseudomonas), and continuing Vanco (for MRSA
   coverage).
   - Continuing Vanc/Zosyn
   -  F/u cultures, continue to re-culture if spikes (all are NTD, sputum
   culture is contaminated)
   - Needs new sputum Cx as the last one was inadequate
   - Rheum recommends  Colchicine for gout treatment; no steroids at this
   time.
   - He has had a left-sided pleural effusion for several days.  Consider
   tapping if persistently febrile.
   - R PICC was just placed [**2109-11-4**] so not likely source.  Will consider
   pulling if we can obtain other access.
   - Would add Flagyl for anaerobes if persistently febrile and no source
   becomes apparent
   - Stopped tylenol and was afebrile
   .
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - Have started Lasix 40 IV bid
   - metoprolol 37.5 mg QID
   - I/O goal
   .
   #) AFib with RVR: dig loaded, level was 1.8 yesterday pm, only getting
   dosed every day. Will discuss on rounds starting on qday dosing.
   - Dose with digoxin today; was held yesterday d/t 1.8 Dig level
   - Metoprolol as above
   - INR very high yesterday, will convert and stop coumadin.
   - F/u coags this am
   .
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Has not had episodes of
   desaturation for several days but continues to require frequent
   suctioning.
   - Vanc/Zosyn as above.
   - diuresis
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - Continue as is, try to wean O2 as tolerated
   .
   #) Delerium: more interactive the last couple of days but continues to
   wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to communicate with his sons and
   they think he has improved.  Almost definitely has hospital/ICU
   delirium.
   - Should continue working with PT.
   - Standing Tylenol for pain control
 will give a trial off Tylenol to
   assess fevers
   - no benzos or other altering medications
   .
   #) Gout: Rheum consulted and tapped knee, fluid is consistent with
   gout. Could explain low grade fevers, increased WBC count.
   - Continues on Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday and we are hesitant to increase
   this further, pt already with delirium and possible infection
   - Started Colchicine yesterday
   - Has been on prednisone despite rheum recs not to be on it, will
   discuss with team today.
   .
   #) Hypotension: resolved.  Will need close monitoring while being
   diuresed.
   .
   #) Left and right wrist fractures: Left side reduced and casted.  Right
   side splinted.  No plans for operative intervention.
   - will recontact ortho to take a look at the L cast which appears to be
   sliding off
   .
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - Touched base with orthopedics who said needs to keep on 6-8wks from
   injury and then f/u with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10823**]
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   .
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   improved to 1.1
   - trend creatinine
   .
    #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.3.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   .
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.  We are giving albuterol and
   ipratropium nebulizers standing
   .
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: holding agents while he has foley in
   place
    .
   FEN: NG tube w/ tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin and pneumo boots, Pepcid
   Access: PICC line
   Code:  Full (discussed with son)
   Communication: Patient, son [**Name (NI) 3080**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10783**].  All three sons
   are very involved.  We may have to discuss PEG tube placement with them
   relatively soon.
   Disposition: Should begin rehab screening.  He would likely do better
   going to acute rehab than to the floor.
   Line:  PICC Line - [**2109-11-4**] 10:00 AM
